oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Proposed designs for gates and stone fence at Chattanooga Cemetery
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three separate ink design drawings contained on one piece of coated fabric that relay sectioning, framing, and elevation in depicting proposed gates and stone fencing for the Chattanooga Cemetery. Scale is 1/2 inch to 1 foot.

After the the Civil War, Wainwright stayed with the Quartermaster Department and helped oversee the location, identification, and re-interment of Union army dead in the National Cemeteries in Knoxcville, Murfreesboro, Chattanooga, and Atlanta. The burial of Union soldiers on the land that was to become the Chattanooga National Cemetery began on Nov. 25, 1863, under orders of General George Thomas. The Wainwright records are the second largest collection of extant Quartermaster records in the nation.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: William Alonzo Wainwright, U.S. Assistant Quartermaster Records, 1861-1870
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Chattanooga National Cemetery; National cemeteries, American; Chattanooga (Tenn.)
Cemeteries; Stone walls; Gates
